Award.AwardTitle: III: Student Travel Fellowships for KDD 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides domestic and international travel support for U.S. based graduate student participants to attend the 22nd ACM SIGKDD Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (KDD 2016), which will be held in San Francisco, CA, USA from August 13-17, 2016. KDD is the world?s premier conference in data science. It is an interdisciplinary conference that brings together ~2000 researchers and practitioners every year from all aspects of data mining, knowledge discovery, and large-scale data analytics. A strong representation of U.S. researchers, particularly students, at the conference is essential in maintaining U.S. competitiveness in this important area today and into the future.

The conference is a highly selective meeting that includes oral and poster presentations of refereed papers as well as panel discussions and invited talks by the leading experts. It provides an international forum for presentation of original research results, as well as exchange and dissemination of innovative and practical development experiences. The total number of KDD participants in recent years has been in excess of 2200, with a majority of the participants being from the U.S., followed by Europe and Asia. For the selection of awardees, the selection committee will put particular emphasis on diversity. As in various STEM fields, increasing the diversity of participants at KDD is a primary goal.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
We received $50,000 in funds from the NSF toward travel support of students from US-based schools to ACM KDD 2016.

We were able to fund a total of 67 students, 66 of whom at $750 each and 1 student at $500.

The students who received support were from all around the US, vaious university and colleges, nationatilities, and gender. We also supported students who did not have any papers or posters to present, to give them the opportunity to experience a professional event like KDD. The statistics of students include the following.

- 22 female students, 45 male students

- 2 undergraduate, 1 Master's, and 64 PhD students

- 60 students who were poster/paper authors, and 7 students with no publication were able to attend.

We thank NSF for enabling this kind and level of support for the professional development of students. With their contributions, the students were able to register and affort part of their travel to San Francisco. We received many 'thank you' emails from students which we wish to forward to NSF (Note: we also recieved funding from the ACM toward travel support for non-US based, international students).

The students were able to attend various outreach events, professional sessions, and keynote talks.

 


Last Modified: 06/08/2017
Modified by: Leman Akoglu
